posts.name: MORTAL ENGINE
posts.cooked: If you‚Äôre given a choice which one would choose - WhatsApp or SMS ?
Between WA gathering my metadata and (potentially) having access to my messages and SMS where virtually everyone can have access to my messages, with a heavy heart, I‚Äôd choose WA.

While that is true, you also have to consider the implications of WhatsApp having acces to everything on your phone if you are giving it media access, which you have to do if you want to send any media. There are however apps for sending SMS which can be trusted (in my opinion), so giving them access to your phone would be less detrimental.

So yes, with a heavy heart, WhatsApp, if you can install it on a separate device. Otherwise, I might chose SMS, depending on the content you want to send.

I don‚Äôt really think it‚Äôs a problem for me. I could use contact and storage scopes to give WA access to just these contacts and folders (or even just particular file) I want. At least in GrapheneOS. I‚Äôm not sure whether scopes are available in standard Android, but I seem to remember there were some changes towards more granular media permission control somewhere around android 14-16. Feel free to correct me if I‚Äôm wrong.

SMS apps might be more trusted when it comes to giving it permissions, but everything you send is basically cleartext and is visible and, by law, stored for years by your mobile service provider.

Even if we assume that WA is totally malicious and knows all your messages, any law enforcement would have to at least request WA to reveal my messages history. It creates friction to access my messages and no one would bother to do this, as long as I‚Äôm not some high value target. While SMS messages are there in my service provider‚Äôs database, freely accessed by law enforcement.

I don‚Äôt do anything to really fear police, but the ease of access combined with easy automatic detection of ‚Äúsuspicious‚Äù messages by predefined keywords or AI carries risk of people being singled out as a criminal by some message taken out of context.

The real life example of this: years ago a friend of mine asked me by SMS if I like shooting my new carbine. Obtaining gun permit in my country isn‚Äôt easy, especially for carbines or rifles and I don‚Äôt own one. So, even though they meant perfectly legal air rifle, the message, without context could be taken as suspicion of owning illegal firearms. Yeah, all the risk for me was search and interrogation, as I was perfectly innocent, but it would be hassle and stress I could live without. Had the same message been sent by WA, I wouldn‚Äôt worry, because Meta couldn‚Äôt care less as long as the info couldn‚Äôt be monetized in some way.

posts.cooked: Carrier Pigeons or stringed-cans. No to Zuck and no to anyone else snooping

Due to the fact that WhatsApp belongs to an American company that is specialized on collecting data from users and use it to manipulate them, I clearly choose SMS over WhatsApp. Because at this moment, I‚Äôm not afraid of my country spying on me, but I definitely don‚Äôt want Meta to collect more data about me than they already have.

Also, SMS is not that big of a problem because the overwhelming majority of my communication is done over Signal. I only use SMS for a selected few people that do not use Signal yet. And these are not people I communicate with very often.
Media access is not required on iOS. They have implemented the Private Access photo picker.
I‚Äôm not sure what is available on iOS, but depending on the variant, this isn‚Äôt an option for android.

short: sms

whatsapp‚Äôs e2ee is some like marketing gimmick, because metadata is revealing enough details.

sms and email are sort of federated, although plain text, but at least there are multiple providers.
